sources_scanned: CSIS (Center for Strategic and International Studies)

signals.title: Nuclear Arms Control Collapse: New START Treaty Expiration in February 2026

source.name: CSIS (Center for Strategic and International Studies)

signals.summary: The New START Treaty between the U.S. and Russia expires in February 2026 with neither nation appearing intent on reaching a new agreement. This marks the end of the last bilateral arms control framework, removing communication mechanisms during nuclear crises. Russia's suspension of inspections since February 2023 has already weakened the treaty framework.
key_signals: New START expiration removes final arms control treaty with Russia
No bilateral arms control mechanisms in place post-2026
Russia demands unilateral Ukrainian concessions before engaging on arms control
Adversarial nuclear coordination expanding among Russia, China, North Korea, Iran
signals.weak_signal_reasoning: This is a weak signal because while the legal expiration is known, the actual behavior shift—whether towards escalation or informal arrangements—remains unresolved. The signal indicates a potential tipping point where nuclear risk management shifts from bilateral frameworks to unilateral coercion strategies.
future_implications: Escalation of nuclear coercion in regional conflicts
Reduced crisis communication during acute tensions
Possible doubling of deployed Russian warheads if arsenal uploaded to maximum
Increased nuclear threshold lowering in conflicts with adversaries

signals.title: Orbital Traffic Management Crisis: Space at Dangerous Tipping Point
signals.summary: RAND Corporation warns that Earth's orbit is becoming dangerously overcrowded with 10,000+ active satellites and 43,000 tracked debris objects creating escalating collision risks. Without international coordination, serious collisions could damage key orbits. There are currently 25 different definitions of space traffic management across governments and industry.
key_signals: 10,000+ active satellites with 43,000 tracked debris objects in orbit
Maneuver avoidance costs reach 25,000 euros per satellite incident
Fragmented global STM systems with incompatible standards
25 different definitions of space traffic management across agencies
signals.weak_signal_reasoning: This is a weak signal because the crisis is still emerging—collisions have not yet triggered major systemic failures—but the fragmented governance structures and escalating satellite deployment create conditions for cascade failures. The lack of unified international standards represents a governance vacuum at a critical moment.
future_implications: Potential Kessler Syndrome triggering cascade collisions
Competitive space race without coordination mechanisms
Need for new international space traffic authority
Emerging space security conflicts between nations

signals.title: Global Cooperation Mechanics Shifting: Multilateralism Declining While Coalition-Based Cooperation Rises

source.name: McKinsey Global Institute / World Economic Forum

signals.summary: The Global Cooperation Barometer 2026 reveals that while overall cooperation levels remain stable, the composition is shifting dramatically. Traditional multilateral mechanisms are declining while smaller, more agile coalitions are maintaining cooperation. Peace and security cooperation fell to pre-COVID levels with every tracked metric declining.
key_signals: Traditional multilateral cooperation declining across tracked metrics
Smaller coalitions replacing large multilateral forums
Peace and security cooperation fell below pre-COVID-19 levels
Military spending rising while conflict resolution mechanisms struggle
signals.weak_signal_reasoning: This is a weak signal of structural transformation in how global governance operates. The shift from inclusive multilateralism to exclusive coalitions suggests the international system is reorganizing around competitive blocs rather than universal institutions—a fundamental governance transition.
future_implications: Emergence of parallel governance systems based on geopolitical alignment
Reduced effectiveness of UN and traditional multilateral institutions
Increased fragmentation of global rules and standards
Greater difficulty addressing global commons issues

signals.title: Information Ecosystem Destabilization: AI Training Models Scraping Content Without Compensation
signals.summary: The WEF highlights an emerging crisis in the information ecosystem as generative AI models consume vast amounts of creator content without fair compensation. Three principles—ownership, openness, and oversight—are identified as necessary guardrails. Creators and publishers face unprecedented value extraction and IP challenges.
key_signals: Generative AI scraping creator/publisher content at scale without compensation
Publishers losing control over content usage and distribution
Need for new IP frameworks for AI training data
Trust erosion in digital ecosystems without transparency
signals.weak_signal_reasoning: This is a weak signal because the conflicts are just emerging—legal frameworks haven't caught up with technical capabilities. The lack of compensation mechanisms and ownership clarity suggests fundamental reordering of digital value chains may occur.
future_implications: Major legal battles over AI training data rights
Potential creator content strikes or removal from training datasets
Emergence of new compensation models for AI-generated value
Fragmented information ecosystems based on data ownership rules

signals.title: AI Skill-Biased Disruption: High-Income Metro Areas Face Heaviest Generative AI Exposure
signals.summary: Generative AI impacts reverse historical automation patterns, hitting high-skill, high-income metros hardest (San Jose 43%, San Francisco, Durham, NYC). Unlike previous waves that harmed low-skill workers, AI targets cognitive office work. Freelancers exposed to AI experienced 2% contract decline and 5% earnings drop. 30%+ of all workers could see 50% of tasks affected.
key_signals: Reversal: AI impacts concentrated in wealthy, educated urban centers
San Jose, SF, Durham, NYC face 40%+ AI task disruption
Freelance earnings down 5% in AI-exposed occupations
Higher-education jobs facing disproportionate exposure vs. manual labor
signals.weak_signal_reasoning: This is a weak signal of emerging inequality inversion—while visible in early freelance market data, broader labor market adjustments haven't yet fully manifested. The geographic concentration in tech hubs suggests emerging bifurcation of opportunity and displacement patterns.
future_implications: Concentration of AI disruption in metropolitan knowledge economies
Growing wage disparities between AI-resilient and AI-exposed roles
Urban affordability crisis as creative professionals face earnings pressure
Mismatch between retraining investments and geographic AI exposure

signals.title: Critical Minerals Geopolitical Weaponization: China's Rare Earth Dominance Reshaping Trade
signals.summary: China controls near-total supply of many critical minerals and rare earth elements, increasingly weaponizing this dominance. The Trump administration is expected to pursue domestic production and allied diversification. This represents a strategic vulnerability for the U.S. and allies dependent on these materials for clean energy and defense.
key_signals: China near-total dominance of critical minerals and rare earth elements
China weaponizing mineral supply as geopolitical leverage
U.S. pursuing domestic critical minerals production
Allied diversification away from Chinese supplies becoming strategic imperative
signals.weak_signal_reasoning: This is a weak signal because while China's dominance is known, the shift towards weaponization and the uncertain success of U.S. alternatives indicate an emerging strategic realignment. New supply chains are still forming, creating volatility.
future_implications: Decoupling of global clean energy supply chains
Price volatility in critical minerals as alternatives developed
Regional geopolitical leverage based on rare earth deposits
Bifurcation of technology standards based on mineral availability

signals.title: Tariff-Driven Inflation Feedback Loop: Consumer Burden Rising to 67% by Mid-2026
signals.summary: U.S. consumers are projected to bear approximately 67% of tariff costs by mid-2026. Goldman Sachs projects inflation contribution from tariffs at 0.3 percentage points in H1 2026. Federal government collected $195 billion in customs duties in FY2025. Treasury officials flagged 'sticky inflation' as a risk, with firms reporting 40% of unit cost growth attributable to tariffs.
key_signals: Consumer tariff burden projected to reach 67% by mid-2026
Goldman Sachs forecasts 0.3pp inflation contribution from tariffs
Sticky inflation risk persists despite economic growth
$195 billion in FY2025 customs duties reshaping fiscal politics
signals.weak_signal_reasoning: This is a weak signal because the full inflationary cascade has not yet materialized. While early indicators show cost pass-through, the ultimate impact on consumption, Fed policy, and wage-price dynamics remains uncertain—creating potential for stagflation.
future_implications: Potential stagflation scenario combining inflation with growth slowdown
Federal Reserve constrained in rate-cutting flexibility
Consumer spending reductions possible if inflation persists
Political pressure for tariff adjustments or exemptions

signals.title: Humanitarian Crisis Acceleration: 20 Countries Facing Record Displacement and Conflict
signals.summary: The International Rescue Committee's 2026 Emergency Watchlist identifies escalating humanitarian crises with the highest levels of conflict since WWII. Crisis-affected 20 watchlist countries represent 12% of world population but 84% of global humanitarian need. Extreme food insecurity, massive displacement, and aid cuts are creating cascade failures in crisis management.
key_signals: 20 countries facing highest conflict levels since WWII
12% of global population accounts for 84% of humanitarian needs
Food insecurity reaching extreme levels in watchlist countries
Global aid cuts contracting despite expanding humanitarian crises
signals.weak_signal_reasoning: This is a weak signal of system breakdown—not yet catastrophic but showing rapid deterioration. The mismatch between escalating crises and collapsing aid suggests humanitarian systems may reach breaking points, with cascade failures in refugee systems, disease control, and conflict prevention.
future_implications: Regional humanitarian collapses triggering migration crises
Disease outbreak risks in high-density displacement camps
Potential state fragility in crisis-affected regions
Geopolitical competition over refugee assistance leverage

key_themes: Space as emerging governance vacuum (orbital debris)
Information ecosystem under fundamental stress (AI training data)
Geographic inversion of automation impacts (metro vs. rural)
Inflation feedback loops from trade policy
Humanitarian system strain and breakdown signals
Multilateral institution erosion with coalition replacement
cross_cutting_signals: Governance frameworks lagging behind technological/geopolitical change
Shift from inclusive multilateralism to exclusive coalitions
Uncompensated value extraction (AI training, minerals, labor)
Geographic concentration of disruption (metros vs. rural; critical minerals regions)
